canonical_explanation.text: Geometrical constructions use ruler and compass to accurately draw line segments, angles, and perpendiculars. Key constructions include copying line segments, constructing perpendicular bisectors, creating angles of 60°, 90°, and 120°, bisecting angles, and drawing perpendiculars from points.
rules: Always use a sharp pencil and compass for accurate constructions
Keep compass width fixed when drawing arcs for a construction
Construction lines and arcs should be light and thin
Label all points clearly with capital letters
A perpendicular bisector divides a line segment into two equal parts at 90°
60° angle is constructed using equilateral triangle properties
90° angle can be constructed using perpendicular bisector method
Angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts
Perpendicular from a point uses arc intersection method

questions.hint: Think about the two basic tools needed to draw accurate geometric figures.
questions.question_text: Which instruments are essential for geometrical constructions?
questions.explanation_correct: Ruler and compass are essential for geometrical constructions because they allow you to accurately draw line segments, angles, and perpendicular lines. The ruler helps you measure and draw straight lines, while the compass is used to create perfect circles and arcs, which are crucial for many construction techniques.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While a ruler and protractor can be used to measure and draw some basic shapes, they are not enough for more complex geometrical constructions. A compass is essential because it allows you to create perfect circles and arcs, which are needed to accurately construct angles, perpendicular lines, and other geometric elements. The set squares and protractor are not the primary tools used in most geometrical constructions.

options.text: Divides it into three equal parts
Divides it into two equal parts at 90°
Divides it into two parts at 45°

questions.hint: The word 'perpendicular' means 90° and 'bisector' means dividing into two equal parts.
questions.question_text: What does a perpendicular bisector do to a line segment?
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector divides a line segment into two equal parts and meets the line segment at a 90-degree angle. This ensures the two parts are exactly the same length, which is the key function of a perpendicular bisector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector does not divide the line segment into three equal parts, nor does it create an angle of 45 degrees. It also does not double the length of the line segment. Instead, it divides the line segment exactly in half, creating two parts that are equal in length and perpendicular to the original line segment.

questions.hint: What triangle has all angles equal to 60°?
questions.question_text: To construct a 60° angle, you should draw arcs that form which shape?
questions.explanation_correct: To construct a 60° angle, you need to draw arcs that form an equilateral triangle. This is because an equilateral triangle has three angles of 60° each, so the arcs will create a 60° angle accurately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct way to construct a 60° angle is to use a compass to draw two arcs that intersect and form an equilateral triangle. This triangle has three angles of 60° each, so the intersection of the arcs will give you the desired 60° angle. Squares, rectangles, and pentagons do not have 60° angles, so those options would not work for this construction.

questions.hint: Bisecting means dividing into two equal parts.
questions.question_text: An angle of 80° is bisected using compass and ruler. What is the measure of each resulting angle?
questions.explanation_correct: Bisecting an 80° angle means dividing it into two equal parts. Since 80° divided by 2 is 40°, the measure of each resulting angle is 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer of 20° is wrong because bisecting an 80° angle does not give two 20° angles. The correct answer of 40° is right because 80° divided by 2 equals 40°, so each resulting angle is 40°.

questions.hint: What is the meaning of 'perpendicular'?
questions.question_text: When drawing a perpendicular from a point on a line, the perpendicular makes an angle of:
questions.explanation_correct: When drawing a perpendicular from a point on a line, the perpendicular line meets the original line at a 90-degree angle. This is because a perpendicular line forms a right angle (90 degrees) with the original line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (45 degrees) and Option D (120 degrees) are incorrect because they do not form a right angle (90 degrees) with the original line. Option B (60 degrees) is also incorrect because a perpendicular line is at a 90-degree angle, not a 60-degree angle.

options.text: Construct a 60° angle and double it
Construct two 60° angles adjacent to each other

questions.hint: Think about how 120° relates to 60°.
questions.question_text: How can you construct a 120° angle using compass and ruler?
questions.explanation_correct: To construct a 120° angle, you can draw two 60° angles side by side. This is because 120° is twice the measure of a 60° angle. By drawing two 60° angles next to each other, you can create a 120° angle using just a compass and ruler.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options would not correctly construct a 120° angle. Doubling a 60° angle would give you 120°, but you can't do that directly with a compass and ruler. Bisecting a 240° angle or adding 30° to a 90° angle would not work either, as those methods would not result in a 120° angle.

options.text: PQ must be parallel to AB
PQ must be perpendicular to AB
PQ must have the same length as AB
PQ must be twice the length of AB

questions.hint: What does 'copying' mean in geometry?
questions.question_text: When copying a line segment AB to create a new segment PQ, what must be true?
questions.explanation_correct: When copying a line segment AB to create a new segment PQ, the length of PQ must be the same as the length of AB. This is because the key purpose of copying a line segment is to create a new line segment that is exactly the same size as the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options suggest that PQ must be parallel, perpendicular, or twice the length of AB. However, these are not requirements when copying a line segment. The only requirement is that PQ has the same length as AB, so that the new segment is an exact copy of the original.

questions.hint: First find half of 90°, then find half of that result.
questions.question_text: If you bisect a 90° angle, and then bisect one of the resulting angles again, what angle do you get?
questions.explanation_correct: If you bisect a 90° angle, you get two 45° angles. Bisecting one of these 45° angles again gives you a 22.5° angle, which is the correct answer (option B).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not make sense because bisecting a 90° angle twice cannot give you 15°, 30°, or 45°. Bisecting a 90° angle first gives you two 45° angles, and then bisecting one of those 45° angles gives you a 22.5° angle, which is the correct answer.

options.text: Points A and B with equal radius

questions.hint: The construction requires arcs from both ends of the segment.
questions.question_text: In constructing a perpendicular bisector of segment AB, arcs are drawn from:
questions.explanation_correct: In constructing the perpendicular bisector of a line segment AB, you need to draw arcs from the endpoints A and B with equal radius. This ensures that the perpendicular line intersects the midpoint of AB, creating the perpendicular bisector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Drawing arcs from only the midpoint would not create a perpendicular line; C) Drawing arcs from any point on AB would not give you the perpendicular bisector; D) Drawing arcs from outside points would not intersect at the midpoint to create the perpendicular bisector. The correct option B, drawing arcs from the endpoints A and B with equal radius, is the key step to constructing the perpendicular bisector.

options.text: Draw a line parallel to l through P
Draw an arc from P intersecting l at two points
Draw a 90° angle at any point on l

questions.hint: You need to create two reference points on the line first.
questions.question_text: What is the first step to draw a perpendicular from a point P outside a line l?
questions.explanation_correct: To draw a perpendicular from a point P outside a line l, the first step is to draw an arc from point P that intersects the line l at two points. This creates a triangle, and the perpendicular line can then be constructed by connecting the point P to the midpoint of the line segment on l.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drawing a parallel line or a 90° angle at a point on l will not help create the perpendicular line from P. Marking the midpoint of l is also not the first step in this construction. The correct first step is to draw an arc from point P to intersect the line l at two points, which then allows you to construct the perpendicular line.

questions.hint: This tool has two legs, one with a point and one with a pencil.
questions.question_text: The instrument used to draw circles and arcs in geometrical constructions is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The instrument used to draw circles and arcs in geometrical constructions is called a compass. This is because a compass has a pointed end that can be placed on a point, and a pencil or pen end that can be used to draw circles and arcs around that point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'compass'. A compass is a tool that has a pointed end and a pencil or pen end. The pointed end can be placed on a point, and the pencil or pen end can be used to draw circles and arcs around that point. This makes it the perfect instrument for geometrical constructions.

questions.hint: All three angles in an equilateral triangle are equal and sum to 180°.
questions.question_text: Each angle of an equilateral triangle measures ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: The angles of an equilateral triangle are all equal. Since an equilateral triangle has three sides of equal length, the angles must also be equal. Each angle of an equilateral triangle measures 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 90°. An equilateral triangle has three angles that are all equal, but the correct measure of each angle is 60°. This is because in a triangle, the sum of the three angles is always 180°, and since all three angles are equal in an equilateral triangle, each one must be 60°.

questions.hint: The bisector divides the segment into two equal halves.
questions.question_text: A perpendicular bisector intersects the line segment at its ___ point.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector intersects the line segment at its mid point, which is the exact middle of the line segment. This is because the perpendicular bisector cuts the line segment into two equal halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mid', which means the middle of the line segment. The perpendicular bisector is a line that meets the line segment at a 90 degree angle and divides it into two equal parts. It intersects the line segment at the midpoint, not at any other point along the line segment.

questions.hint: Divide the angle measure by 2.
questions.question_text: When a 110° angle is bisected, each of the two equal angles formed measures ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: When a 110° angle is bisected, it is divided into two equal angles. Since 110° divided by 2 is 55°, each of the two equal angles formed measures 55°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 55. However, the incorrect answer would be 110° / 2 = 55°. This is because bisecting an angle means dividing it into two equal parts. So, if the original angle is 110°, then each of the two equal angles formed after bisection will be 55°.

questions.hint: What is a right angle?
questions.question_text: A line perpendicular to another line forms an angle of ___° with it.
questions.explanation_correct: A line perpendicular to another line forms an angle of 90 degrees with it. This is because perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a perfect right angle, which measures 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle between a line and a perpendicular line to it is not 60 degrees or 120 degrees. Those angles are special angles that can be constructed using a ruler and compass, but they are not the angle formed by a perpendicular line. The correct answer is 90 degrees, because perpendicular lines intersect at a right angle.

questions.hint: What angle added to itself equals 120°?
questions.question_text: To construct a 120° angle, you can draw two ___ angles next to each other.
questions.explanation_correct: To construct a 120° angle, you can draw two 60° angles next to each other. This is because 60° + 60° = 120°, so combining two 60° angles creates a 120° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 60 degrees. To construct a 120° angle, you need to draw two 60° angles next to each other. This is because 60° + 60° = 120°. So, the missing word in the question is '60'.

questions.hint: What property of the segment are we duplicating?
questions.question_text: When copying a line segment, we use a compass to measure and transfer the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When copying a line segment, we use a compass to measure and transfer the length of the original line segment to the new location. This allows us to create an identical copy of the line segment with the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'length'. When copying a line segment, we use a compass to measure the length of the original line segment, not the angle or any other property. We then use the compass to transfer this length to the new location, creating a copy with the same length as the original.

questions.hint: The prefix 'bi-' means two.
questions.question_text: An angle bisector divides an angle into ___ equal parts.
questions.explanation_correct: An angle bisector is a line that divides the angle into two equal parts. So, the correct answer is that an angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that an angle bisector divides an angle into three equal parts. This is not correct because an angle bisector always divides the angle into two equal halves, not three. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'two'.

questions.hint: This special name is used for exactly 90°.
questions.question_text: A 90° angle is also called a ___ angle.
questions.explanation_correct: A 90° angle is called a right angle because it forms a perfect 'L' shape, with the two lines meeting at a 90 degree angle. This is one of the key angle constructions that we learn in geometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'right' angle. A right angle is 90 degrees, meaning the two lines meet at a perfect square or 'L' shape. Other common angle constructions include 60 degree and 120 degree angles, but a 90 degree angle is specifically called a 'right' angle.

questions.hint: What are the two end points of a line segment called?
questions.question_text: The perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from both ___ of the segment.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from both endpoints of the segment because it divides the segment into two equal halves. This means that the distance from the perpendicular bisector to each endpoint is the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector of a segment is not equidistant from the midpoint of the segment. Instead, it is equidistant from the two endpoints of the segment. The perpendicular bisector is a line that passes through the exact middle of the segment and is perpendicular to the segment.

questions.hint: Think about the essential tools mentioned in construction basics.
questions.question_text: A ruler and compass are the only tools needed for basic geometrical constructions.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, that's true. A ruler and compass are the only tools needed for basic geometrical constructions. These tools allow you to accurately measure and draw lines, angles, and other shapes that are needed in geometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, that's not correct. While a ruler and compass are the main tools used for basic geometrical constructions, you may sometimes need additional tools like a protractor to measure and construct specific angles like 60 degrees or 120 degrees. The ruler and compass alone won't be enough for all types of constructions.

questions.hint: What does the word 'bisector' mean?
questions.question_text: A perpendicular bisector divides a line segment into two unequal parts.
questions.explanation_correct: A perpendicular bisector divides a line segment into two equal parts. This is because the perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint of the line segment, cutting it exactly in half.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A perpendicular bisector does not divide a line segment into two unequal parts. The perpendicular bisector is a line that intersects the original line segment at a right angle and passes through the midpoint, creating two equal halves. So the statement is false.

questions.hint: Can you construct 60° using compass and ruler alone?
questions.question_text: To construct a 60° angle, you must use a protractor.
questions.explanation_correct: You can construct a 60° angle using just a ruler and compass, without needing a protractor. This is one of the key geometrical constructions that can be done accurately with these basic tools.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To construct a 60° angle, you can use a simple construction with a ruler and compass. First, draw a line segment. Then, use the compass to mark off two equal lengths on the line. Finally, connect the endpoints to create a 60° angle. So a protractor is not needed for this construction.

questions.hint: Calculate half of 120°.
questions.question_text: Bisecting a 120° angle will result in two 60° angles.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, that's true. If you bisect a 120° angle, you will get two 60° angles. This is because a 120° angle can be divided into two equal parts, and each part will be 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, that's not correct. If you bisect a 120° angle, you do not get two 90° angles. Instead, you get two 60° angles. This is because a 120° angle can be divided into two equal parts, and each part will be 60°.

questions.hint: What angles are formed when a line is divided by a perpendicular?
questions.question_text: A perpendicular from a point on a line creates two right angles.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, this is true. When you draw a perpendicular line from a point to another line, it creates two right angles (90 degrees) on either side of the perpendicular line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is incorrect because a perpendicular line creates not just one, but two right angles. When you draw a perpendicular line from a point to another line, it divides the original line into two equal halves and forms two 90 degree angles on either side of the perpendicular line.

questions.hint: What is special about all the angles in an equilateral triangle?
questions.question_text: All angles in an equilateral triangle are equal to 60°.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, all angles in an equilateral triangle are equal to 60°. This is because an equilateral triangle has three sides of equal length, and the sum of the angles in any triangle is always 180°. When divided equally, each angle in an equilateral triangle is 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, the statement is not correct. A common mistake is to think that the angles in an equilateral triangle are not equal to 60° each. However, this is incorrect. An equilateral triangle has three sides of equal length, and the sum of the angles in any triangle is always 180°. When divided equally, each angle in an equilateral triangle is 60°.

questions.hint: Does copying require the same direction or just the same length?
questions.question_text: When copying a line segment, the new segment must be parallel to the original.
questions.explanation_correct: The new line segment does not have to be parallel to the original. When copying a line segment, you can draw the new segment at any angle or orientation, as long as it is the same length as the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not correct. When copying a line segment, the new segment can be drawn at any angle or orientation, not just parallel to the original. The key is to make sure the new segment is the same length as the original, not that it is parallel.

questions.hint: What happens when you add the two parts back together?
questions.question_text: An angle bisector creates two angles that together equal the original angle.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, that's correct! An angle bisector divides an angle into two equal halves. This means the two new angles created by the angle bisector are equal in size and add up to the original angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not correct. An angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts, not two angles that add up to the original angle. For example, if you have a 60 degree angle and draw the angle bisector, it will create two 30 degree angles. The two new angles add up to 60 degrees, which is the original angle.

questions.hint: Think about angles on opposite sides of a straight line.
questions.question_text: A 120° angle can be constructed by first making a 60° angle and then extending it on the opposite side of the base line.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, this is true. A 120° angle can be constructed by first making a 60° angle and then extending it on the opposite side of the base line. This is because two 60° angles together make a 120° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be thinking that a 120° angle cannot be constructed this way. But in fact, it can be constructed by first making a 60° angle and then extending it on the opposite side of the base line. This is because two 60° angles together make a 120° angle.

questions.hint: Can you drop a perpendicular from an external point to a line?
questions.question_text: A perpendicular can be drawn from a point that lies outside a given line.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, a perpendicular can be drawn from a point that lies outside a given line. This is possible using a compass and ruler to construct the perpendicular line from the point to the given line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that a perpendicular can only be drawn from a point that lies on the given line. However, this is not true. Using a compass and ruler, we can construct a perpendicular line from any point, even if it is outside the given line. The key is to use the construction steps to accurately draw the perpendicular line.

ordering_items: Draw the original line segment AB
Set compass width equal to length AB
Draw a baseline through point P
Place compass at P and draw arc on baseline
Mark intersection point as Q, so PQ = AB
questions.hint: Start with the original segment, then measure and transfer the length.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to copy a line segment AB to point P in correct order:
correct_answer: Draw the original line segment AB
Set compass width equal to length AB
Draw a baseline through point P
Place compass at P and draw arc on baseline
Mark intersection point as Q, so PQ = AB
questions.explanation_correct: The steps are arranged correctly because they show the logical sequence of actions needed to copy a line segment AB to point P using a compass. First, you draw the original line segment AB. Then, you set the compass width to the length of AB. Next, you draw a baseline through point P, place the compass at P, and draw an arc on the baseline. Finally, you mark the intersection point Q, which will have the same length as the original line segment AB.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The steps are not arranged correctly. The correct order is: 1) Draw the original line segment AB, 2) Set the compass width equal to the length of AB, 3) Draw a baseline through point P, 4) Place the compass at P and draw an arc on the baseline, 5) Mark the intersection point Q, so PQ = AB. This sequence ensures that the new line segment PQ has the same length as the original AB.

ordering_items: Draw line segment AB
Set compass to radius more than half of AB
Draw arcs from A above and below AB
Draw arcs from B with same radius intersecting previous arcs
Join the two intersection points to form perpendicular bisector
questions.hint: The arcs must be drawn from both endpoints with the same radius.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to construct a perpendicular bisector of segment AB:
correct_answer: Draw line segment AB
Set compass to radius more than half of AB
Draw arcs from A above and below AB
Draw arcs from B with same radius intersecting previous arcs
Join the two intersection points to form perpendicular bisector
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of steps is important to accurately construct the perpendicular bisector of a line segment. By first drawing the segment, then setting the compass to more than half the length, and finally drawing the intersecting arcs, you can precisely locate the points that define the perpendicular line passing through the midpoint of the segment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to start by drawing the perpendicular bisector line directly, without first constructing the necessary arcs. This approach does not provide a reliable way to accurately locate the midpoint and perpendicular line. The correct steps involve using the compass to draw intersecting arcs, which then allow you to precisely identify the points that define the perpendicular bisector.

ordering_items: Draw ray AB with A as vertex
Place compass at A and draw an arc cutting AB at point P
Keep same compass width and place compass at P
Draw another arc intersecting the first arc at Q
Join A to Q to form 60° angle
questions.hint: This construction uses the equilateral triangle property with equal radii.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to construct a 60° angle at point A on ray AB:
correct_answer: Draw ray AB with A as vertex
Place compass at A and draw an arc cutting AB at point P
Keep same compass width and place compass at P
Draw another arc intersecting the first arc at Q
Join A to Q to form 60° angle
questions.explanation_correct: The steps are in the correct order because they show how to construct a 60° angle using a compass. First, we draw the ray AB with A as the vertex. Then we use the compass to draw an arc cutting AB at point P. Keeping the same compass width, we place the compass at P and draw another arc that intersects the first arc at Q. Finally, we join A to Q to form the 60° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The steps are not in the correct order. To construct a 60° angle at point A on ray AB, you need to first draw the ray AB with A as the vertex. Then, you place the compass at A and draw an arc cutting AB at point P. With the same compass width, you place the compass at P and draw another arc that intersects the first arc at Q. Finally, you join A to Q to form the 60° angle.

ordering_items: Draw angle AOB with vertex at O
Place compass at O and draw arc intersecting OA at P and OB at Q
Place compass at P and draw an arc in the interior of angle
Place compass at Q with same radius and draw arc intersecting previous arc at R
Join O to R to create the angle bisector
questions.hint: You need to create intersection points on both arms first, then arcs from those points.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to bisect an angle AOB:
correct_answer: Draw angle AOB with vertex at O
Place compass at O and draw arc intersecting OA at P and OB at Q
Place compass at P and draw an arc in the interior of angle
Place compass at Q with same radius and draw arc intersecting previous arc at R
Join O to R to create the angle bisector
questions.explanation_correct: The steps to bisect an angle AOB are correct because they involve using a compass to precisely draw arcs that intersect to find the point R, which is then connected to the vertex O to create the angle bisector. This ensures the angle is divided exactly into two equal parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect steps would be to not use the compass properly or to skip important steps. For example, failing to draw the initial arcs intersecting the angle sides at P and Q, or not using the same compass radius to draw the intersecting arcs at R. These steps are crucial to accurately locate the angle bisector line.

ordering_items: Draw line l and mark point P on it
Place compass at P and draw arcs on both sides cutting l at A and B
Set compass to radius more than AP
Draw arcs from A and B above/below line l intersecting at Q
Join P to Q forming perpendicular
questions.hint: First create two equidistant points on the line from P, then construct from those points.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to draw a perpendicular from point P on line l:
correct_answer: Draw line l and mark point P on it
Place compass at P and draw arcs on both sides cutting l at A and B
Set compass to radius more than AP
Draw arcs from A and B above/below line l intersecting at Q
Join P to Q forming perpendicular
questions.explanation_correct: The steps given are the correct way to draw a perpendicular from a point P to a line l. First, we mark the point P on the line l. Then, we use the compass to draw arcs from P that intersect the line l at points A and B. Next, we set the compass to a radius greater than the distance from P to the line, and draw arcs above and below the line from A and B. Where these arcs intersect is the point Q, and joining P and Q forms the perpendicular line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to draw the perpendicular line in a different order. For example, trying to join P and Q directly without first finding the points A, B, and Q would not work, as you would not know where to place the perpendicular line. The steps given in the correct answer are necessary to accurately construct the perpendicular line using a ruler and compass.

ordering_items: Draw line l and mark external point P
Place compass at P with suitable radius and draw arc cutting l at two points A and B
Place compass at A and draw arc below line l
Place compass at B with same radius and draw arc intersecting previous arc at Q
Join P to Q, which is perpendicular to l
questions.hint: The first arc from P must cut the line at two points to create reference locations.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to draw perpendicular from external point P to line l:
correct_answer: Draw line l and mark external point P
Place compass at P with suitable radius and draw arc cutting l at two points A and B
Place compass at A and draw arc below line l
Place compass at B with same radius and draw arc intersecting previous arc at Q
Join P to Q, which is perpendicular to l
questions.explanation_correct: The steps provided are the correct way to draw a perpendicular line from an external point P to a given line l. This is because by drawing arcs with the compass from point P and the two points where the arc intersects the line l, you can determine the point Q that is perpendicular to l from P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect explanation would be to simply join P directly to the line l. This would not create a perpendicular line. The key steps are to use the compass to draw the arcs and find the point Q that is perpendicular to the line l from the external point P.

ordering_items: Draw a ray with vertex at point O
Construct first 60° angle from the ray
Keep compass at same width
Construct second 60° angle adjacent to first
The angle between the base ray and final ray is 120°
questions.hint: Build 120° by adding two 60° angles together.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to construct a 120° angle:
correct_answer: Draw a ray with vertex at point O
Construct first 60° angle from the ray
Keep compass at same width
Construct second 60° angle adjacent to first
The angle between the base ray and final ray is 120°
questions.explanation_correct: The correct steps to construct a 120° angle are: 1) Draw a ray with vertex at point O, 2) Construct the first 60° angle from the ray, 3) Keep the compass at the same width, 4) Construct the second 60° angle adjacent to the first, 5) The angle between the base ray and final ray is 120°. This works because two 60° angles added together make a 120° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect steps would be: 1) Draw a ray with vertex at point O, 2) Construct a 90° angle from the ray, 3) Keep the compass at the same width, 4) Construct another 90° angle adjacent to the first, 5) The angle between the base ray and final ray is 180°. This is incorrect because two 90° angles added together make a 180° angle, not a 120° angle.

ordering_items: Read the construction problem carefully
Draw a rough sketch of the required figure
Perform the construction using compass and ruler
Mark and label all important points
Verify the construction is accurate
questions.hint: Think about the logical flow from planning to execution to verification.
questions.question_text: Arrange the general steps for any geometric construction:
correct_answer: Read the construction problem carefully
Draw a rough sketch of the required figure
Perform the construction using compass and ruler
Mark and label all important points
Verify the construction is accurate
questions.explanation_correct: This is the correct order of steps for any geometric construction. It's important to first carefully read the problem to understand what needs to be constructed. Then, a rough sketch can help visualize the figure. Next, use the compass and ruler to carefully construct the figure step-by-step. Finally, mark and label all important points, and verify that the construction is accurate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to start by performing the construction using compass and ruler, without first reading the problem carefully or drawing a rough sketch. This could lead to mistakes, as you may not fully understand what needs to be constructed. It's also important to mark and label all important points, and verify the accuracy of the final construction, to ensure it meets the requirements of the problem.

ordering_items: Draw a base ray
Construct a 60° angle from the ray
Identify the 60° angle formed
Bisect the 60° angle
The resulting angle is 30°
questions.hint: 30° is half of 60°, so use bisection after constructing 60°.
questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to construct a 30° angle using compass and ruler:
correct_answer: Draw a base ray
Construct a 60° angle from the ray
Identify the 60° angle formed
Bisect the 60° angle
The resulting angle is 30°
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is the sequence of steps to construct a 30° angle using a compass and ruler. First, you draw a base ray. Then, you construct a 60° angle from the ray. This gives you the 60° angle. Next, you bisect this 60° angle, which results in the desired 30° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect sequence would be to first draw the 60° angle, then identify it, and then bisect it. This would not work because you need to first draw the base ray, then construct the 60° angle, and only then can you bisect that angle to get the 30° angle. The final step of the correct sequence is recognizing that the resulting angle is 30°.

ordering_items: Measure AP and PB where P is intersection point
Verify that AP = PB (bisection property)
Measure angles formed at P
Verify that angles at P are 90° each (perpendicular property)
Confirm perpendicular bisector is complete
questions.hint: Check both properties: equal division and right angles.
questions.question_text: Arrange the properties verified after constructing perpendicular bisector of AB:
correct_answer: Measure AP and PB where P is intersection point
Verify that AP = PB (bisection property)
Measure angles formed at P
Verify that angles at P are 90° each (perpendicular property)
Confirm perpendicular bisector is complete
questions.explanation_correct: The given order is correct because it follows the logical steps to verify the properties of a perpendicular bisector. First, you measure the lengths of the two line segments on either side of the intersection point. Then you check if they are equal, which confirms the bisection property. Next, you measure the angles formed at the intersection point and verify they are 90 degrees, showing the perpendicular property. Finally, you confirm the construction is complete.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order is not correct. The first step should be to measure AP and PB to confirm they are equal in length, which verifies the bisection property. Then you should measure the angles at the intersection point P and check that they are 90 degrees each, confirming the perpendicular property. Only after verifying these two key properties should you confirm that the perpendicular bisector construction is complete.

questions.question_text: What is the their uses: of Compass?

options.text: Dividing segment into two equal parts at 90°

questions.hint: Match each tool or construction with what it does.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Drawing arcs and circles. The compass is a key tool used in geometric constructions to draw perfect circles and arcs, which are important for many construction techniques.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The compass is not used for drawing straight lines (option A), as that can be done with just a ruler. It is also not used for dividing a segment into two equal parts at 90 degrees (option D), as that is done using other construction methods. While the equilateral triangle property (option B) is important, the compass is primarily used for drawing circles and arcs, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: What is the their uses: of Ruler?

options.text: Dividing segment into two equal parts at 90°

questions.hint: Match each tool or construction with what it does.
questions.explanation_correct: The main use of a ruler is to draw straight lines. By placing the ruler on the paper and tracing along it, you can create accurate, straight line segments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While a ruler can be used to measure line segments and construct perpendicular lines, its primary purpose is to draw straight lines. Options A and B describe other geometrical constructions, but a ruler is not the main tool used for those. Option D is also incorrect, as a ruler cannot be used to directly draw arcs or circles - that requires a compass.

questions.question_text: What is the their uses: of Perpendicular bisector?

options.text: Dividing segment into two equal parts at 90°

questions.hint: Match each tool or construction with what it does.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector is used to divide a line segment into two equal parts at a 90-degree angle. This means it cuts the line segment exactly in half, forming a perfect right angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector is not used for constructing equilateral triangles or drawing arcs and circles. It is also not used for drawing straight lines. The main purpose of the perpendicular bisector is to divide a line segment into two equal parts at a 90-degree angle, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: What is the their uses: of 60° construction?

options.text: Dividing segment into two equal parts at 90°

questions.hint: Match each tool or construction with what it does.
questions.explanation_correct: The 60° construction is used to draw equilateral triangles. An equilateral triangle has all three angles equal to 60°, so using this construction allows you to accurately draw this type of triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 60° construction is not primarily used for drawing straight lines, dividing segments at 90°, or drawing arcs and circles. Its key use is constructing equilateral triangles, which are triangles with all three angles equal to 60°. This property of equilateral triangles is what makes the 60° construction useful.

questions.question_text: What is the construction method: of 60°?
questions.hint: Think about how each angle can be constructed with compass and ruler.
questions.explanation_correct: The equilateral triangle method is the correct way to construct a 60° angle. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three angles equal to 60°, so by drawing an equilateral triangle, you can easily construct a 60° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other methods are not the correct way to construct a 60° angle. Perpendicular bisectors and bisecting a 60° angle do not give you a 60° angle. Making two adjacent 60° angles would give you a 120° angle, not a 60° angle.

questions.question_text: What is the construction method: of 90°?
questions.hint: Think about how each angle can be constructed with compass and ruler.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector method is the correct way to construct a 90-degree angle. By drawing a perpendicular line that bisects another line, you can easily create a perfect right angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct way to construct a 90-degree angle. Equilateral triangles have 60-degree angles, not 90-degree angles. Bisecting a 60-degree angle will give you a 30-degree angle, not a 90-degree angle. And two adjacent 60-degree angles do not add up to 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the construction method: of 120°?
questions.hint: Think about how each angle can be constructed with compass and ruler.
questions.explanation_correct: The construction of a 120° angle is done by drawing two adjacent 60° angles. This is because an equilateral triangle has three 60° angles, so two of these angles together make a 120° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct method for constructing a 120° angle. Bisecting a 60° angle would give you a 30° angle, not a 120° angle. Using the equilateral triangle method would give you a 60° angle, not a 120° angle. The perpendicular bisector method is not used to construct 120° angles.

questions.question_text: What is the construction method: of 30°?
questions.hint: Think about how each angle can be constructed with compass and ruler.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct method to construct a 30° angle is to bisect a 60° angle. This means you divide the 60° angle exactly in half to create two 30° angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The construction method to create a 30° angle is not by creating an equilateral triangle, which has three 60° angles. It is also not by adding two adjacent 60° angles, which would create a 120° angle. The perpendicular bisector method is used to create 90° angles, not 30° angles.

questions.question_text: What is the result of 80°?
questions.hint: Divide each angle by 2 to find the bisected result.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 40°. This is because if we construct an angle of 80°, the remaining angle will be 180° - 80° = 100°. The angle that is the supplement of 100° is 80°, which is 180° - 100° = 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not represent the supplement of an 80° angle. The supplement of an angle is the angle that, when added to the original angle, equals 180°. So the correct answer is 40°, which is the supplement of 80°.

questions.question_text: What is the result of 100°?
questions.hint: Divide each angle by 2 to find the bisected result.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 50°. This is because when you bisect (divide in half) an angle of 100°, the result is two equal angles of 50° each.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is 45°. Bisecting an angle of 100° would not result in 45°, as 45° is half of 90°, not half of 100°. The correct answer is 50°, since 100° divided by 2 is 50°.

questions.question_text: What is the result of 140°?
questions.hint: Divide each angle by 2 to find the bisected result.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 70°. This is because 140° divided by 2 is 70°. When we bisect an angle, we split it into two equal parts. So, the result of bisecting 140° is an angle of 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not represent the result of bisecting 140°. 40°, 45°, and 50° are not the angles obtained when we bisect 140°. The correct answer is 70° because when we divide 140° by 2, we get 70°, which is the result of bisecting the original angle.

questions.question_text: What is the result of 90°?
questions.hint: Divide each angle by 2 to find the bisected result.
questions.explanation_correct: A right angle is 90°. This is one of the key angles that can be constructed using a ruler and compass. So, the result of 90° is 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct angle of 90° is created by constructing a perpendicular line. This means the lines meet at a 90-degree angle. The other options like 50°, 70°, and 40° are not right angles and cannot be accurately constructed using just a ruler and compass.

questions.question_text: What is the key feature: of Copying line segment?
questions.hint: What is the defining characteristic of each construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The key feature of copying a line segment is that the new line segment has the same length as the original one. This allows you to accurately draw a line of the same size as the one you're copying.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that the new line segment has the same length as the original one. The other options are not the key features of copying a line segment. Intersecting at the midpoint, shortest distance to the line, and having two equal angles are not the main things you need to do when copying a line segment using a ruler and compass.

questions.question_text: What is the key feature: of Perpendicular bisector?
questions.hint: What is the defining characteristic of each construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The key feature of a perpendicular bisector is that it intersects the line at the midpoint. This means the perpendicular bisector divides the line into two equal parts, with the midpoint being exactly in the center.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector is not the shortest distance to the line. It is also not about creating two equal angles, nor is it about the length being the same as the original line. The key feature is that the perpendicular bisector intersects the line at the exact midpoint, dividing it into two equal parts.

questions.question_text: What is the key feature: of Perpendicular from external point?
questions.hint: What is the defining characteristic of each construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The key feature of a perpendicular drawn from an external point to a line is that it forms the shortest distance between the point and the line. This is because the perpendicular line is always at a right angle (90 degrees) to the original line, making it the most direct path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the key feature of a perpendicular from an external point. The perpendicular line does not necessarily intersect at the midpoint of the line, nor does it have to be the same length as the original line. Additionally, while the perpendicular line does create two equal angles, this is not the defining feature - the key aspect is that it forms the shortest distance between the point and the line.

questions.question_text: What is the key feature: of Angle bisector?
questions.hint: What is the defining characteristic of each construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The key feature of an angle bisector is that it creates two equal angles. This means the angle is divided into two parts of the same size or measurement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that an angle bisector creates two equal angles. This is because the angle bisector divides the angle exactly in half, creating two angles of the same size. The other options are not the key features of an angle bisector. An angle bisector does not intersect at the midpoint, it is not the shortest distance to the line, and it does not have the same length as the original angle.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Bisector?
questions.hint: Match each term with its definition.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) Divides into two equal parts. A bisector is a line that cuts a shape or angle into two equal halves or parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because: B) All sides equal refers to a different shape called a regular polygon, not a bisector. C) Drawing with compass and ruler is the general method for geometric constructions, not the definition of a bisector. D) At 90° angle refers to a perpendicular line, not a bisector.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Perpendicular?
questions.hint: Match each term with its definition.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) At 90° angle. Perpendicular means two lines that intersect at a perfect right angle, or 90 degrees. This means the lines form a square corner, not a slanted or angled corner.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A) All sides equal and option B) Divides into two equal parts are not the definitions of perpendicular. Option D) Drawing with compass and ruler is a method of constructing perpendicular lines, but it does not define what perpendicular means. The correct answer is C) At 90° angle, which means the lines intersect at a right angle of 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Equilateral?
questions.hint: Match each term with its definition.
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral shape is one where all the sides are equal in length. This means that an equilateral triangle has all three sides the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) All sides equal. This means that in an equilateral shape, all the sides have the same length. Option A) Drawing with compass and ruler is not the meaning of equilateral. Option B) Divides into two equal parts describes a bisector, not an equilateral shape. Option D) At 90° angle describes a right angle, not an equilateral shape.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Construction?
questions.hint: Match each term with its definition.
questions.explanation_correct: Construction means to draw shapes and figures using a ruler and compass. Option C is correct because it describes the process of making geometrical shapes by using these tools.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D do not correctly describe the meaning of construction. A and D refer to properties of shapes, while B refers to the angle between two lines. Construction is the process of drawing shapes and figures using a ruler and compass, as shown in option C.

questions.question_text: What is the characteristic: of Perpendicular bisector arcs?

options.text: Arc intersects line at two points

questions.hint: Think about the steps and properties of each perpendicular construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment is constructed by drawing arcs from both endpoints of the line segment. This ensures that the perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint of the line segment and forms 90-degree angles with the line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment is constructed by drawing arcs from both endpoints of the line segment. This ensures that the perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint of the line segment and forms 90-degree angles with the line. The other options are incorrect because the perpendicular bisector does not simply form 90-degree angles, it intersects the line at two points, and it does not create two right angles - it creates one right angle at the midpoint of the line segment.

questions.question_text: What is the characteristic: of Perpendicular from point on line?

options.text: Arc intersects line at two points

questions.hint: Think about the steps and properties of each perpendicular construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The characteristic of a perpendicular from a point on a line is that it creates two right angles (90°) with the line. This is because a perpendicular line intersects the original line at a 90-degree angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct option is D - it creates two right angles. This is because a perpendicular line from a point to another line will intersect the line at a 90-degree angle, forming two right angles on either side. Options A and B describe other geometric constructions, not the characteristics of a perpendicular line.

questions.question_text: What is the characteristic: of Perpendicular from external point?

options.text: Arc intersects line at two points

questions.hint: Think about the steps and properties of each perpendicular construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Arc intersects line at two points. This is a characteristic of a perpendicular line drawn from an external point to another line. The arc drawn with the compass intersects the line at two points, forming a perpendicular line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly describe the characteristic of a perpendicular line drawn from an external point. Option A is incorrect because a perpendicular line forms a 90-degree angle with the original line, not just any angle. Option B is incorrect because the perpendicular line is drawn from a single external point, not both endpoints. Option D is incorrect because the perpendicular line creates two right angles, not just one.

questions.question_text: What is the characteristic: of All perpendiculars?

options.text: Arc intersects line at two points

questions.hint: Think about the steps and properties of each perpendicular construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct option is D because a perpendicular line always forms a 90° angle with the original line. This means the perpendicular line meets the original line at a perfect right angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not accurate descriptions of perpendicular lines. Option A is wrong because a perpendicular line intersects the original line at only one point, not two points. Option B is incorrect because perpendiculars are drawn from a single point, not both endpoints of a line. Option C is incorrect because perpendiculars create one right angle, not two.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 60° angle?
questions.hint: How many 60° angles are needed to make each angle?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of a 60° angle is one 60° angle. This is because 60° is a specific measure of an angle, and there is only one way to draw a 60° angle using a ruler and compass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because three 60° angles would add up to 180°, not 60°. Option C is incorrect because half of 60° would be 30°, not 60°. Option D is incorrect because two 60° angles would add up to 120°, not 60°. The correct answer is option B, which states that the value of a 60° angle is one 60° angle.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 120° angle?
questions.hint: How many 60° angles are needed to make each angle?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of a 120° angle is two 60° angles. This is because we can divide a full circle (360°) into six equal 60° angles, and two of these 60° angles add up to 120°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 120° angle is not half of a 60° angle, nor is it three 60° angles. It is also not just one 60° angle. The correct answer is that a 120° angle is made up of two 60° angles, which add up to 120°.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 180° angle?
questions.hint: How many 60° angles are needed to make each angle?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D) Three 60° angles. This is because 180° is the measure of a straight angle, and a straight angle can be divided into three 60° angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately represent the value of a 180° angle. Option A) is half of 60°, which is 30°. Option B) is just one 60° angle, which is less than 180°. Option C) is two 60° angles, which is 120°, which is also less than 180°.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 30° angle?
questions.hint: How many 60° angles are needed to make each angle?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of a 30° angle is half of a 60° angle. This is because 60° is a key angle that can be constructed using a ruler and compass, and 30° is exactly half of 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Half of 60° angle. This is because a 60° angle is one of the key angles that can be constructed using a ruler and compass, and 30° is exactly half of 60°. The other options are incorrect because a 30° angle is not equal to one 60° angle (option B), three 60° angles (option C), or two 60° angles (option D).

questions.question_text: What is the purpose: of Setting compass width?
questions.hint: What is the purpose of each step in a construction?
questions.explanation_correct: Setting the compass width ensures equal distances because it allows you to accurately measure and copy line segments. This is an important step in many geometric constructions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose of setting the compass width is not to create intersection points, form lines, or identify construction elements. These are all separate steps in geometric constructions. Setting the compass width is specifically about ensuring the distances you measure and copy are equal and accurate.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose: of Drawing arcs?
questions.hint: What is the purpose of each step in a construction?
questions.explanation_correct: Drawing arcs is important in geometrical constructions because it creates intersection points that are used to construct the required shapes, like lines, angles, and perpendiculars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not fully describe the purpose of drawing arcs in geometrical constructions. Option B is incorrect because arcs are not just used to identify construction elements, but to actually create the required shapes. Option C is incorrect because arcs are not directly used to form the required line, but rather they create the intersection points that are then used to draw the line. Option D is incorrect because arcs are not primarily used to ensure equal distances, but to construct the needed geometrical shapes.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose: of Joining points with ruler?
questions.hint: What is the purpose of each step in a construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The purpose of joining points with a ruler is to form the required line segment. By connecting two points with a straight line using a ruler, you can accurately draw the line that you need for your construction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose of joining points with a ruler is not to ensure equal distances or identify construction elements. While these may be useful in some constructions, the main reason for using a ruler to connect points is to create the specific line that is required for the construction. By drawing a straight line between the points, you form the line segment that you need to complete the construction.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose: of Labeling points?
questions.hint: What is the purpose of each step in a construction?
questions.explanation_correct: The purpose of labeling points in geometrical constructions is to identify and keep track of the different elements used in the construction, such as line segments, angles, and intersections. Labeling helps you remember what each part of the construction represents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Identifies construction elements. Labeling points is not about creating intersection points, ensuring equal distances, or forming the required line. It's about clearly marking the different parts of the construction so you can follow the steps and understand what each element represents.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 90°?
questions.hint: Classify each angle based on its measure.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct unit for 90° is a right angle. A right angle is one of the basic angles in geometry, formed when two perpendicular lines meet. It is always 90 degrees, or a quarter of a full circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, a straight angle, is incorrect because a straight angle is 180 degrees, not 90 degrees. Option B, an obtuse angle, is also incorrect because an obtuse angle is greater than 90 degrees. Option C, an acute angle, is incorrect because an acute angle is less than 90 degrees. The correct option is D, a right angle, which is exactly 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 60°?
questions.hint: Classify each angle based on its measure.
questions.explanation_correct: A 60° angle is an acute angle, which means it is less than 90°. This makes option D the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct units for a 60° angle. An obtuse angle is greater than 90°, a straight angle is 180°, and a right angle is exactly 90°. A 60° angle is an acute angle, which is less than 90°.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 120°?
questions.hint: Classify each angle based on its measure.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Obtuse angle. A 120° angle is an obtuse angle, which is an angle greater than 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is an obtuse angle, which is greater than 90°. A right angle is 90°, and an acute angle is less than 90°. So the unit for 120° is an obtuse angle, not a straight angle, right angle, or acute angle.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 180°?
questions.hint: Classify each angle based on its measure.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Straight angle. A straight angle is an angle that measures 180 degrees, which is exactly half of a full circle or rotation (360 degrees).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct unit for 180 degrees. A right angle is 90 degrees, an acute angle is less than 90 degrees, and an obtuse angle is greater than 90 degrees, but none of these are equal to 180 degrees. The correct answer is a straight angle, which measures 180 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the value of Perpendicular bisector?
questions.hint: Count how many arcs are drawn in each construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment is constructed using four arcs - two arcs from each endpoint. This ensures that the constructed line is perpendicular to the original line segment and bisects it exactly in the middle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector is not constructed using just one arc for length, or one arc from the vertex, or three arcs total. It requires four arcs - two arcs from each endpoint of the line segment. This ensures that the constructed line passes through the midpoint of the line segment and is perpendicular to it.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 60° angle?
questions.hint: Count how many arcs are drawn in each construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D. A 60° angle is constructed using one arc from the vertex. This is because a 60° angle is one-sixth of a full circle, and the arc that subtends one-sixth of the circle has an angle measure of 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately describe how a 60° angle is constructed. Option A is incorrect because the length of the line segment is not determined by the number of arcs. Option B is incorrect because a 60° angle is constructed using only one arc, not three. Option C is incorrect because the 60° angle is constructed using only one arc from the vertex, not four arcs.

questions.question_text: What is the value of Angle bisector?
questions.hint: Count how many arcs are drawn in each construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C. Three arcs total. When constructing an angle bisector, you draw two arcs from the endpoints of the angle. The intersection of these two arcs gives you the point on the angle bisector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately describe the construction of an angle bisector. Option A (one arc from vertex) is incorrect because you need two arcs, one from each endpoint. Option B (one arc for length) is incorrect because the length of the arcs is not the key feature, but rather the intersection point of the two arcs. Option D (four arcs) is incorrect because you only need two arcs, one from each endpoint, to construct the angle bisector.

questions.question_text: What is the value of Copying line segment?
questions.hint: Count how many arcs are drawn in each construction.
questions.explanation_correct: The value of Copying a line segment is to draw one arc from one endpoint of the line segment. This arc shows the length of the line segment, which can then be copied onto a new line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is to draw one arc from one endpoint of the line segment. This is because when copying a line segment, you only need to measure the length of the line, which can be done by drawing a single arc from one endpoint. Drawing multiple arcs or arcs from the vertex would not accurately copy the length of the line segment.
